data.title: Status Bar doesn't indicate a watch-task
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 8/10

I created a Gulp task that does `gulp.watch`, and added `"isWatching": true` to a `tasks.json`.
When the task is running, the Status Bar doesn't indicate an icon (spinner) that means a watch-task.

To reproduce, I created a new project that is the same as an example:
https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/languages/markdown#_automating-markdown-compilation
I did those steps faithfully.
And, when the task is running, the Status Bar doesn't indicate a watch-task.

I tried to remove `"isWatching": true` from the `tasks.json`, then the Status Bar indicated it.
It seems that the task and the Status Bar work fine.
(But, is VS Code still waiting for the finish of the task because since `isWatching` isn't set?)

data.title: Create `jsconfig.json` in Configure Excludes if it does not exist
data.body:
Fixes #16846

The intended behavior is that we will create a temp `jsconfig.json` in the root of the workspace if one does not exist (this same error that #16846 will shows up for implicit projects which have `jsconfig.json` paths in `/dev/null`). The user can then edit and save this file

data.title: "Unable to write settings" message bar should have button to open User Settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.8.0 Insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add an extra trailing comma to user settings.json.
2. Close the settings file.
3. Try to toggle File > AutoSave.

You see the "Unable to write settings. Please open User Settings to correct..." message. 
We should add a button to open User Settings next to Close.

data.title: Add a few casts to work around issues in ts 2.1.4
data.body: A few errors show up when compiling vscode with TS 2.1.4

data.title: Improve exception experience
data.body:
For details see https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/1007

We could consider to revive the Peek UI.

data.title: [Feature Request] Loading git executable from WSL
data.body:
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Anniversary Update)

Hi, since WSL is now available to provide easier access to multiple command line utilities that were normally only available as workaround for windows, is there a possibility to allow VSCode to access the git executable installed on Bash instead of either being forced to maintain two git updated with ssh keys or start vscode from the bash command line (which is currently not supported but would completely solve this issue)

data.title: Moving cursor across folded code should not automatically unfold
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.16

Folding code is often a strategy for hiding parts of files that aren't important or relevant to the current task and making it more manageable to scroll up / down. Given this context, I propose that when code is folded, it should perhaps remain folded until the user explicitly wants to unfold it. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fold code
2. Attempt to move cursor over folded code

Example:

![dec-07-2016 15-51-21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3681045/20986072/10e8d29a-bc95-11e6-8686-4c5a30577d75.gif)

Desired Behavior:

1. Fold code
2. Be able to move cursor past line of folded code without auto-unfolding

data.title: Errors from TextModelResolverService can have PII
data.body:
At https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/textmodelResolver/common/textModelResolverService.ts#L84 we throw an error if the resource cannot be found.

The `resource` can have PII and should be scrubbed.

There are 3 ways this can be done

1. Scrub PII before logging the error. Downside is that even the error in the console will not have the resource and we lose out on info that could help in debugging with a user
2. Update the `telemetryService` code to scrub the error. This would need the telemetryservice to be aware of the file pattern in use
3. Use console.log() to log the error and then return rejected promise instead of error

data.title: Just my code debugging is ignoring a skip file in the workspace root when using node
data.body:
#16208

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (0d65ced0fa7398dc9d50c39a23a2a8cc8406ff18, 2016-12-07T07:04:22.691Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-27-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|lorem-ipsum|Tyriar|1.0.0|
|theme-glacier|Tyriar|0.0.10|
|vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.7.1|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.0.0|
|Theme-Wombat|gerane|0.0.2|
|md-navigate|jrieken|0.0.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.50|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.5.3|
|java|redhat|0.0.7|
|annotator|ryu1kn|0.10.1|

---

1. Clone and open https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express.git
2. Created the launch.json:

    ```js
    {
        // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
        // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
        // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
        "version": "0.2.0",
        "configurations": [
            {
                "type": "node2",
                "request": "launch",
                "name": "Launch Program",
                "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/www",
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
                "skipFiles": [
                    "file.js"
                ]
            },
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "attach",
                "name": "Attach to Process",
                "port": 5858
            }
        ]
    }
    ```

3. Create `bin/file.js`:

    ```js
    module.exports = {
        test: function() {
            console.log('foo');
        }
    };
    ```

4. Add this to bin/www:

    ```js
    var file = require('./file');
    file.test();
    ```

5. Put a breakpoint on the `file.test()` call
6. Start debugging
7. Hit the breakpoint
8. Step in, the code is skipped correctly
9. Change `type` to `node`
10. Repeat 6-8, the debugger will incorrectly go inside file.js

data.title: Allow to configure files.exclude from the explorer
data.body:
Testing #16534

Would be nice to simply right-click on a folder to automatically add to jsconfig.json and exclude it from a project. Also would be nice for folders to have some sort of visible indication that they are excluded. 

I think this sort of functionality would be useful for most language services, so having a generic way to tie in would be handy (I've certainly used it myself in WebStorm)

<hr>

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (7499a9f3c565f4fbe5205e30c8664e5a5a11ae94, 2016-12-06T16:16:15.865Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14965

data.title: Debug: Having skipFiles will skip native node APIs when using node but not with node2
data.body:
#16208

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (0d65ced0fa7398dc9d50c39a23a2a8cc8406ff18, 2016-12-07T07:04:22.691Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-27-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|lorem-ipsum|Tyriar|1.0.0|
|theme-glacier|Tyriar|0.0.10|
|vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.7.1|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.0.0|
|Theme-Wombat|gerane|0.0.2|
|md-navigate|jrieken|0.0.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.50|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.5.3|
|java|redhat|0.0.7|
|annotator|ryu1kn|0.10.1|

---

1. Clone and open https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express.git
2. Created the launch.json:

    ```js
    {
        // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
        // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
        // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
        "version": "0.2.0",
        "configurations": [
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "launch",
                "name": "Launch Program",
                "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/www",
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
                "skipFiles": [
                    "node_modules/**" // Intentionally doesn't match `http` module
                ]
            },
            {
                "type": "node",
                "request": "attach",
                "name": "Attach to Process",
                "port": 5858
            }
        ]
    }
    ```

3. Put a breakpoint at `bin/www:28` on `server.listen`
4. Start debugging
5. Hit the breakpoint
6. Step in, notice `http` *is* skipped
7. Change `type` to `node2` in `launch.json`
8. Start debugging
9. Hit the breakpoint
10. Step in, notice `http` *is not* skipped

data.title: More specific more specific Configure Excludes message
data.body:
Testing #16534

Related to #16757

Few ideas:
* make it clearer what the specific action is the user should perform - (if it fits) consider referencing the property itself "use the'exclude' property to exclude... then restart the window"
* consider adding a link to documentation in the status bar 
* consider adding infobar that pops up after you click the "configure excludes" that gives you a link to reload the window
* Make it clear that this isn't just about better performance - we literally don't have any completions at this point, right? "JavaScript/TypeScript completions disabled... "
 
<hr>

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (7499a9f3c565f4fbe5205e30c8664e5a5a11ae94, 2016-12-06T16:16:15.865Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14965

Instead of continually stepping in which is very time consuming, could it just step out once a skip file is reached?

data.title: Completions list displays never-ending "loading..." when "Configure Excludes" warning is enabled
data.body:
Testing #16534

When TS gets disabled, the user's focus is on the completion list, not on the status bar - we should provide better text in the completions list to warn the user that those completions are never going to appear, no matter how long they wait (e.g. what if we displayed "Completions not available", and a hyperlink to "Configure Excludes"?)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/20982852/0e2f3bc8-bc6f-11e6-9796-d55814f99654.png)

<hr>

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (7499a9f3c565f4fbe5205e30c8664e5a5a11ae94, 2016-12-06T16:16:15.865Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14965

All keys that are in the **Most Commonly Used** section are reported as duplicated keys.

data.title: [Feature] Copy entire output from Debug Console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: **1.7.2**
- OS Version: **Windows**

Steps to Reproduce:

*  Try `Ctrl-A` so you can select everything to copy, 
*  Or try highlighting and scrolling in the Debug Console output to get everything.

Either situation *won't* work you can only select by highlighting text that's currently visible within the Output window in the debug console. Ctrl-A (select all) doesn't work in the debug window for some reason either.

It'd be great to be able to either have a button, or just be able to do Ctrl-A (whichever) so you could copy/paste and look through some large output that came out.

data.title: Intellisense reports type of imported modules as "import <...>" instead of actual type
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.8.0-insider - OS Version: Mac OSX 10.11 Where TStep is defined, Intellisense reports the type as `React.Requirable`

data.title: Update Seti-icons to match Seti-UI
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Fedora 25 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

After a recent update to Seti-UI for Atom, the Seti-icons for VS-Code has fallen out of sync with Seti-UI for atom. Some additional icons and updates to icons (namely icons, like puppet, were updated to match the new logo). Attached is a screenshot of the same folder open both vscode and atom showing the difference:

![seti-vscode-atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2914211/20981968/424bf39e-bc7c-11e6-8b5e-a6b163570c74.png)


EDIT: Upload better comparison

data.title: Windows PowerShell should be the default terminal program on Windows
data.body:
I'd like to recommend making PowerShell the default terminal program on Windows when the user hasn't configured their path (and when the `COMSPEC` environment variable hasn't been explicitly set).  Since PowerShell will now be the default terminal program in Windows 10 going forward ([see blog post](https://blogs.windows.com/windowsexperience/2016/11/17/announcing-windows-10-insider-preview-build-14971-for-pc/)), I think it makes sense to make it the default in VS Code on Windows as well.

What do you think?

data.title: Filter unbound commands from watermark
--extensions-dir not accepting relative path on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.8.0-insider (7499a9f3c565f4fbe5205e30c8664e5a5a11ae94, 2016-12-06T16:16:15.865Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|regex|chrmarti|0.0.7|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.0.7|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.5.39|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Does not start: code-insiders.cmd --user-data-dir tmp\user --extensions-dir tmp\exts
2. Does start: code-insiders.cmd --user-data-dir tmp\user --extensions-dir c:\Users\chrmarti\tmp\exts

data.title: Double edit range with snippets
data.body: * have a snippet like this `${brot:8008}$0` * insert snippet (via command or IntelliSense) * 🐛 you see two boxes at one point...
